channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tensions Erupt in Brussels, and Police in 4 Countries Make Arrests
item.description: Memorials for the victims of the terrorist attacks in Brussels were interrupted on Sunday by far-right protesters.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Sabrina Esmael Fazal, Nursing Student and Brussels Victim
item.description: Ms. Fazal, 24, grew up in Ottignies, Belgium. She was killed in the attack at the Maelbeek train station.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Explosion at Park in Lahore, Pakistan, Kills Dozens
item.description: The blast, which appeared to be caused by a suicide bomber, occurred at a park popular with families, killing at least 69 people and wounding around 300.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: An injured man was tended to after the blast in Lahore.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Keep the Militias Out of Mosul
item.description: Iraq’s government successfully retook Ramadi last year with an inclusive, nonsectarian strategy. Let’s repeat that.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SALEEM AL JUBOURI

item.title: Syrian Troops Said to Recapture Historic Palmyra From ISIS
item.description: The nearly yearlong occupation of the ancient city, a Unesco World Heritage site, came to an end after a three-week push by President Assad’s forces.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: In a photo released by the state media, Syrian forces look over the ancient town of Palmyra on Sunday.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 52, Mostly Women, Kids in Pakistan Park
item.description: A suicide bomber killed at least 52 people, mostly women and children, at a public park in the Pakistani city of Lahore on Sunday, government officials and police said, striking at the heart of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's political base of Punjab.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: After an Indictment, Turks Give U.S. Prosecutor a Hero’s Welcome Online
item.description: A Twitter post announcing charges against the tycoon Reza Zarrab has made Preet Bharara, U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, a social media sensation.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, in Albany in February. Mr. Bharara has become a social media sensation in Turkey.

item.title: Reporter’s Notebook: With Obama Visit to Cuba, Old Battle Lines Fade
item.description: The president’s engagement policy and Raúl Castro’s minor opening to free-market ideas have created a new dynamic for Cuba that reveals what the country could become with more freedom to evolve.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Havana on Thursday, a man on a laptop and others on cellphones took advantage of a Wi-Fi hot spot. Many clamor for more access to the Internet, which remains extremely limited in Cuba.

item.title: Sent Home to Australia, but Still Jailed for Chinese Crimes
item.description: Part of a prisoner exchange, Matthew Ng says he is now incarcerated for crimes he did not commit in a nation that would not consider his actions illegal.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Matthew Ng, center in blue, was escorted by officers outside a court in Guangdong, China, in March 2012. He was sentenced to more than 12 years in prison on charges of bribery and fraud.

item.title: Another First for Cuba: A Concert by the Rolling Stones
item.description: Cuban music fans hoped Mick Jagger would break down the gates to political and social change that Cuban leaders had already cracked open.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cubans and foreign tourists cheered for Mick Jagger on Friday at the Ciudad Deportiva sports facility in Havana.

item.title: North Koreans Rely on Smuggled Cellphones to Connect to the Outside World
item.description: Mobile phones smuggled from China are an increasingly vital way for North Koreans to reach relatives who have defected abroad.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Choi Hyun-joon, a North Korean defector, on the streets of Seoul, the capital of South Korea. Calls made using a Chinese cellphone helped facilitate the defection of his daughter.

item.title: U.S. Accountants Who Found Adventure in Europe Among Brussels Victims
item.description: Officials on Saturday confirmed the deaths of Justin and Stephanie Shults, a couple who had settled in Belgium.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN
item.media:description: Justin and Stephanie Shults in a photograph taken from social media. Mr. Shults’s death was confirmed on Saturday.

item.title: A Dual Citizen of Belgium and Italy, With a Cosmopolitan Spirit
item.description: Patricia Rizzo, killed in the Brussels attacks, was at home in both countries, and an independent streak motivated her to move back and forth between the two.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Patricia Rizzo, a dual citizen of Belgium and Italy, died in the attack near Brussels’ Maelbeek station this week.

item.title: Migrants in Greece, Ready to Go Anywhere in Europe, Scramble to Enter E.U. Relocation Program
item.description: Once Germany-bound, many refugees stranded in Greece are hoping the program will come through for them as European security tightens after the Brussels attacks.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m afraid people will think we are all Daesh,” said Ahmed Arab, a Syrian refugee, last week at his Athens apartment.

item.title: New Brussels Attack Suspect Is Charged, Prosecutors Say
item.description: A man identified in the Belgian press as Fayçal Cheffou has been accused of terrorist murders. The authorities say he was deeply involved in the plot.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Turkey Abruptly Closes Espionage Trial of 2 Journalists to Public
item.description: The move was criticized by journalists and anti-government and human rights activists who wondered if the defendants could receive a fair trial.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: From left, Can Dundar, the top editor at Cumhuriyet, a Turkish daily, and Erdem Gul, its Ankara editor, arrived at a courthouse Friday in Istanbul for their trial on espionage charges.

item.title: Frank Deng, ‘Spirited’ Chinese Entrepreneur and Brussels Victim
item.description: Deng Jingquan, also known as Frank Deng, had founded in Internet start-up not long after finishing college.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Deng Jingquan, also known as Frank Deng, was a technology entrepreneur and frequent traveler.

item.title: Najim Laachraoui, 24, Bomb Maker for Paris and Brussels Attacks
item.description: What is known about a former engineering student who blew himself up at Brussels Airport on March 22.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE and AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: A man the Belgian police said was Najim Laachraoui in an undated photo posted by the agency on Twitter.

item.title: Headed to U.S. for a Belated Celebration, Jennifer Scintu-Waetzmann Dies in Brussels Attacks
item.description: Jennifer Scintu-Waetzmann and her husband were traveling to New York City for their first anniversary. She died in the attack, and he is in a coma.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR
item.media:description: Jennifer Scintu-Waetzmann in a photo taken from social media.

item.title: André Adam, Retired Diplomat and Brussels Victim
item.description: A foreign service career that included posts with the United Nations and in the United States, Africa, Europe and Cuba.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and ELI ROSENBERG
item.media:description: André Adam, a retired ambassador, was on his way to the United States on Tuesday when he was killed in the attack at Brussels Airport.
